<summary>
1. The phase-field method is a popular tool for simulating microstructure formation during solidification.
2. The method relies on describing the geometry in terms of one or several phase fields, which are governed by partial differential equations.
3. The equations can be solved using numerical methods, but the accuracy of the simulations depends on the choice of equations and the numerical methods used.
4. The phase-field method has limitations, such as the difficulty in dealing with thin interfaces and the presence of multiple length scales.
5. Thin-interface limits are a way to simplify the equations and make them more tractable, but they can only be applied under certain conditions.
6. Antitrapping currents are a generalization of the thin-interface limit that can be used to eliminate the temperature jump at the interface.
7. The antitrapping current can be derived from the standard phase-field equation by introducing a new interpolation function.
8. The antitrapping current can be used to adjust the temperature jump at the interface and restore continuity of the temperature between the two sides of the interface.
9. In addition to the antitrapping current, there is another thin-interface effect that can arise in the two-sided case, known as the kapitza resistance.

• The interstellar medium (ISM) of a typical disk galaxy is divided into various phases, including hot ionized gas, warm neutral medium, and cold neutral medium.
• Star formation is restricted to cold dense gas, and the link between star formation and molecular gas is not causal, as the presence of molecules simply marks regions that are cold enough to undergo gravitational collapse.
• Understanding the crucial links between star formation, the ISM, and galaxy evolution requires identifying the pathways and conditions under which cold, molecular gas is able to develop.

• The VRC and supra-clump are found to have the same color and magnitude as stars in the core helium-burning phase of evolution, as predicted by isochrones.
• The VRC is likely to be due to stellar evolution rather than an intervening population, as the color and magnitude of the substructures are consistent with the expected evolutionary changes of stars in the LMC.
• The VRC and supra-clump are found to have a @xmath28% uncertainty in their fraction due to counting statistics alone, which is consistent with the estimate of @xmath29% by Zl.

• The paper presents a fast and efficient method to calculate the inclusive 2p-2h responses in the relativistic Fermi gas model (RFG).

<summary>
• The reverberation mapping technique is used to estimate the mass of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in active galactic nuclei (AGNs).

* The technique relies on the fact that the continuum emission from the AGN variates on timescales of hours to days, while the broad emission lines (BELs) lag behind by several months.

* By measuring the time lag between the continuum and BELs, the SMBH mass can be estimated using the velocity dispersion of the BELs and the assumption of virial equilibrium.

* The reverberation mapping technique has been used to estimate SMBH masses in a large number of AGNs, but the method is observationally taxing and requires a large amount of telescope time.

* The correlation between the continuum luminosity and the time lag of the BELs is well established, but there is a lower limit to the SMBH mass due to the lack of observations of low luminosity AGNs.

* Recent revisions to the correlation between the continuum luminosity and the SMBH mass have been made, but more observations are needed to establish a complete picture.

* The technique is useful for estimating SMBH masses from single-epoch spectra and can be used to calibrate other surrogate relations used for black hole mass estimates.

* The authors of the paper present optical spectroscopic and photometric observations of a new low luminosity AGN, H 0507+164, and estimate the SMBH mass using the reverberation mapping technique.
</summary>

• The broad emission iron lines are well-known features found in the spectra of active galactic nuclei and black hole binaries, and are believed to originate close to the black hole due to reflection of the primary radiation on the accretion disc. • The spin of the black hole affects the shape of the line, with higher spin values resulting in a more compact marginally stable orbit and a lower boundary of the broad line, which can be used to estimate the spin of the black hole.

* The European Space Agency's (ESA) Ste-Quest mission is a medium-sized mission candidate for launch in 2022/2024 to study the equivalence principle and test the universality of free fall.
* The mission aims to measure the gravitational redshift experienced by highly accurate clocks in the gravitational fields of Earth or Sun, and to test the predictions of General Relativity and other theories.
* The mission consists of a space segment and a ground segment, with the space segment including a satellite, two instruments (atomic clock and atom interferometer), and science links for precise orbit determination.
* The ground segment is composed of three ground terminals that are connected to highly accurate ground clocks, and the mission objectives are to measure the frequency shift of the space clock due to the gravitational redshift and to compare the frequency of the ground clocks with the space clock.

<summary>

* The paper discusses the propagation of high-frequency (HF) electromagnetic (EM) waves in the ionosphere and their interaction with the plasma.
* The authors use numerical simulations to study the propagation of an HF EM wave into the ionosphere, with ionospheric parameters typical for the high-latitude EISCAT heating facility in Troms, Norway.

* The simulation neglects the field-aligned irregularities in the ionosphere and assumes a vertically stratified ion number density profile.
* The EM wave is injected vertically into the ionosphere with spatial variations only in the @xmath3 direction.

* The simulation shows that the HF EM wave propagates without changing shape through the neutral atmosphere until it reaches the ionospheric layer.
* At the turning point of the r-x and l-o modes, the EM wave undergoes Faraday rotation due to the different dispersion properties of the two modes.

* The l-o mode oscillations at @xmath37 km are radiating EM waves with perpendicular electric field components, while the r-x mode is concentrated into a pulse with a single maximum at @xmath38 km.
* The leading part of the pulse is primarily r-x mode polarized, while its trailing part is l-o mode polarized.

* The simulation also shows the excitation of weak turbulence in the ionosphere, which is excited by the HF EM wave.
* The weak turbulence leads to the excitation of electrostatic waves, which are observed to have a wavelength of approximately 33 m and a frequency that decreases with increasing wavenumber.

* The paper highlights the importance of considering the interaction between the HF EM wave and the ionosphere in order to accurately model the propagation of the wave.
* The results of the simulation have important implications for the study of ionospheric turbulence and the excitation of electrostatic waves in the ionosphere.
</summary>

<summary>
* The article discusses the Mott-Hubbard model of interacting bosons in a lattice, which exhibits a phase transition from a superfluid to an insulator.
* The model is described by the mott-hubbard Hamiltonian, which includes on-site repulsion and kinetic energy terms.
* The authors use a perturbative approach to study the short-range correlations in the system, which are important for experimentally measurable observables such as expansion patterns.
* The gutzwiller mean-field ansatz is used to obtain an approximate variational solution for the mott-hubbard Hamiltonian, but it fails to describe the correct behavior of short-range correlations.
* Perturbative corrections are derived to improve the gutzweller wavefunction, and the resulting expressions are used to calculate observables up to second order in perturbation theory.
* The results show important modifications to single-site observables, order parameter, compressibility, and number fluctuations, which are sensitive to the correlations between lattice sites.
</summary>

* The authors propose that this particle, called the light scalar glueball, could be the higgs boson of strong interactions.

• The paper discusses the problem of estimating a signal in the presence of noise, with a particular focus on the phenomenon of stochastic resonance.
• The authors propose two schemes of observations: observing only the proportion of time spent by the perturbed signal over the threshold, or measuring the energy of the signal when it is above the threshold.
• The authors study the asymptotic properties of estimators for the two schemes, and show that the estimators are asymptotically equivalent to the maximum likelihood estimators.

• The parameter space of the HCAMSB model is constrained by experimental and theoretical constraints, which can be used to predict the mass spectra of sparticles.
• The HCAMSB model can have a distinctive signature in LHC events, which can be used to distinguish it from the MAMSB model.

• The article discusses the development of a new approach to the zero-range potential (ZRP) model in quantum mechanics.
• The approach involves using Darboux transformation to construct an exact solution for the Schrödinger equation with a central potential.
• The authors demonstrate that the ZRP model can be solved using the dressed wavefunction method, which involves dressing the zero-range potential with a set of orthogonal functions.
• The dressed potential is shown to have a real part that is regular on the real axis and a imaginary part that is regular on the complex plane.
• The article also discusses the application of the ZRP model to the study of electron scattering by atoms and molecules.
• The authors show that the ZRP model can be used to calculate the integral cross sections for electron scattering by atoms and molecules.
• The article highlights the advantages of the ZRP model over other approaches to electron scattering, including its ability to reproduce the deep minimum in the experimental data.
• The authors conclude that the ZRP model provides a new and powerful tool for studying electron scattering by atoms and molecules.
</summary>

• The paper discusses the numerical solution of the convection-diffusion equation using the differential quadrature method (DQM).
• The DQM is an approximation method that uses cubic spline functions to represent the solution of the equation.
• The paper presents three test problems to illustrate the accuracy and adaptability of the method.
• The method is based on the idea of dividing the problem domain into smaller subdomains and approximating the solution using cubic spline functions.
• The paper also discusses the use of modified extended cubic b-splines and exponential cubic b-splines as base functions for the DQM.

The paper discusses the evolution and environmental dependence of the galaxy luminosity function (LF) based on a redshift survey of the Corona Borealis supercluster. The survey used the Norris spectrograph to obtain redshifts for 1654 galaxies, of which 400 lie behind the supercluster and 1257 lie in a background supercluster.

The paper finds that the LF of galaxies in the supercluster is consistent with a steep faint-end slope, but with a large scatter, and that the normalization of the LF is uncertain due to the small number of galaxies in the survey. The paper also finds that the LF of galaxies in the background supercluster is consistent with a flat faint-end slope, but with a large scatter.

* The study examines the rapidity gap phenomenon in hadronic collisions at both the HERA collider and the Tevatron.
* The authors find that the color singlet fraction in the two-gluon exchange model is too large to be compatible with unitarity, and that the non-perturbative effects are essential for a proper description of the data.
* The unitarized model is able to describe the trend of the data, even though it is an extension of the two-gluon exchange model.
* The comparison with the data shows that the current perturbative approach has limitations, and that a non-perturbative description is necessary to fully understand the rapidity gap phenomenon.
</summary>

* The proposed model uses historical data from 1994 to 2013 to predict energy consumption for 2012 and 2013.
* The performance of the model is evaluated using different error criteria, and the results show that the proposed ann model can accurately predict future trends of electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
* The study demonstrates the effectiveness of the ann approach in tackling the problem of electric energy consumption forecasting, and highlights the potential of ann models for similar applications in the future.

• LMCX-2 is a persistent X-ray binary with a compact object accreting matter from a low-mass companion.
• The binary has an orbital period of 0.32 days and a semi-amplitude of 41 km s@xmath3.
• The companion star is irradiated, leading to the presence of narrow emission lines in the spectra.
• The emission lines are identified as coming from the irradiated side of the companion, providing constraints on the system parameters of LMCX-2.
• The spectra of LMCX-2 show a dramatic change in the intensity of the HeII @xmath14686 line and the Bowen region during the second night of observations.
• The change in intensity is not seen in the equivalent widths of the HeII lines and the Bowen region.
• The continuum flux of LMCX-2 decreases by 94% during the second night, suggesting a common origin for the changes in the emission lines.
• The radial velocity curve of LMCX-2 shows a sine-like variation, which is interpreted as orbital motion of a region co-rotating with the binary.
• A Lomb-Scargle period search reveals a significant peak at a period of 0.32 days, which is consistent with the photometric period detected by Callanan et al. (1990).

* The authors argue that current models for salient object detection have limitations, such as focusing on scenes with single objects and neglecting the complexity of real-world scenes with multiple objects.
* The paper aims to provide solutions to these limitations by addressing the first challenge of selecting objects to process and the second challenge of segmenting the object area.

• The aim of physics is not only to calculate observables but to understand the physical phenomena behind them.
• In quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry is the most important phenomenon, which leads to the appearance of the octet of pseudoscalar mesons and the dynamical mass of quarks.
• The nonzero value of the quark condensate implies that there is a big dynamical mass for quarks, which can be considered as a moment-dependent quantity.
• The constituent quarks acquire a dynamical mass due to the nonperturbative gluon and quark-antiquark dressing.
• The octet of pseudoscalar mesons arises from the associated approximate goldstone bosons in the large @xmath8 limit.
• The valence quarks get dressed by the quark condensates and by the meson loops.
• The spin-orbit force associated with the vector-meson exchange interaction is big and empirically very important in nucleon-nucleon (nn) system.
• In baryons, the spin-spin interaction between constituent quarks is of crucial importance, and the net spin-orbit and tensor forces are rather weak.
• The chiral interaction is explicitly flavor-dependent, which allows to solve the long-standing problem of ordering.
</summary>

• The invention relates to novel calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical devices and processes for making them, which minimize immune responses to the implant.
• The unique coatings minimize inflammation and restenosis, and store and release medication in a controlled manner.
• The coatings are made of calcium phosphate materials, including hydroxyapatite (HA), which are biocompatible and biodegradable.
• The coatings are deposited using thermal or biomimetic deposition methods, which allow for controlled porosity and drug encapsulation.
• The coatings bond poorly to metallic surfaces but bond well to previously consolidated hydroxyapatite, providing a novel and inventive route to achieve high bonding strength and drug encapsulation capability.
• The invention offers a novel approach to drug delivery control and biocompatibility in implantable medical devices, and could lead to improved treatment outcomes and reduced side effects.

• The present invention relates to a fabricated implantable nerve guidance conduit (NGC) that bridges the stumps of a damaged nerve.
• The NGC comprises an inner spiral structured porous sheet with two reserved chambers at the proximal and distal ends.
• The spiral structure is made of a highly porous polycaprolactone (PCL) sheet that is decorated with surface channels and coated with aligned electrospun fibers.
• The dense outer fibrous tube on the outside of the spiral structured porous sheet prevents the infiltration of scar tissue while the regeneration process takes place.
• The NGC has an integrated spiral structured porous sheet decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers.
• The spiral structure provides superior mechanical strength compared to NGCs in the prior art, along with integrated multiple channels, stable aligned fibrous layers, good inter-cell communication, and high surface/volume ratios within the NGCs.
• The chambers at the distal and proximal ends of the NGC provide additional space for fitting nerve stumps in order to reduce the tension at the suture line between the NGC and the nerve stump.
• The dense outer fibrous tube on the outside of the spiral structured porous sheet can prevent the infiltration of scar tissue while the regeneration process takes place.
• The NGCs of the present invention are superior to those in the prior art in that mechanical properties are greatly improved and favorable for inter-cellular interaction and neural myelination.

<summary>
* The invention relates to seat base support assemblies for furniture or the like.
* The invention finds particular advantage in sinuous band spring assemblies, but the invention is not limited thereto.
* The invention provides a new and improved rail connector for sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flexible steel bands.
* The rail connector embodies salutary features of conventional helical spring connectors while retaining none of their undesirable features.
* The connector produces spring torsioning and dynamic uplift at the back rail through kinetic energy stored in the arced sinuous spring itself.
* The invention provides seat spring-enhancing connectors that combine the four essential seat-force-generators, including torsioning, dynamic uplift, expansion-contraction, and leverage-amplification.
* The invention provides varying degrees of dynamic uplift resilience by offering alternative spring action modes within the connector.

• The present disclosure relates to an anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device.
• The anvil assembly includes an anvil shaft and an anvil head assembly, and the anvil shaft defines a first longitudinal bore.
• The anvil head assembly supports an anvil plate that defines a plurality of staple deforming pockets, and a stabilizing collet defines a second longitudinal bore.
• The collet is positioned within the first longitudinal bore and is secured to the anvil shaft, preventing damage to the plurality of flexible legs.
• The collet has a distal end including a plurality of cantilevered fingers, each of which has a protrusion configured to secure the collet within the first longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft.
</summary>

• The invention provides a metal lining (cylindrical member) to shield the inner wall of the receptacle, reducing the impact of collisions with rigid objects.
• The lining is selected from metal, glass, or a hard, non-alloy material, and is combined to the inner wall of the cup by injection molding.
• The lining is shaped as a half-mask, only shielding the lower half of the cup, allowing users to see the whirling vegetable and fruit fibers.
• The lining is combined to the cup to form a shield screen, and a number of teeth projected from the inner wall of the lining are applied to grate fibers of vegetable and fruit.
• The teeth are arranged in a parallel or crossed shape, and the lining is made of a hard, non-alloy material to reduce the impact of collisions.
• The cup has a handle and a spout, and several vertical ribs are protruded from the inner wall, corresponding stopper members are formed on the obverse side of the wall of the lining.
• The hollowed troughs of the stopper members are formed on the reverse side of the wall of the lining, and the vertical ribs and stopper members are received into the hollowed troughs.
• The lining is selected from metal, glass, or a hard, non-alloy material, and the top end of the lining has an L-type wall bended outward and upward.
• The bottom end of the lining has an L-type wall bended inward and downward, and both L-type walls are embedded into the inner wall of the cup to eliminate the permeation of liquid through a chink on the wall.
</summary>

<summary>
* The garnish pick is designed to hold garnishes with one or more appendages emerging from a main shaft, angled toward a sharp end of the main shaft. (1027)
* In embodiments where the garnish pick comprises a plurality of appendages, such appendages may project from a main shaft of the garnish pick at the same or different angles relative to each other along a longitudinal axis and/or an orthogonal axis of the main shaft. (1027)
* The garnish pick may comprise two, three, four, five, or more appendages that each project from a main shaft or other base appendage at different angles relative to each other as measured relative to a longitudinal axis of the main shaft or other base appendage. (1027)
* The garnish pick may be made of wood, plastic, metal, glass, ceramic, or any other rigid, flexible, and/or strong material depending on implementation. (1026)

• The present invention relates to a device and algorithm for a combined cardiomyostimulator and cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator.
• The invention operates to deliver stimulation to a skeletal muscle grafted about a heart and sense depolarizations of a patient's heart.
• The invention detects the occurrence of a first type of arrhythmia when the number of measured intervals falling within a first interval range equals a first predetermined value.
• The invention delivers a first type of arrhythmia therapy in response to the detection of the first arrhythmia.
• The invention detects the occurrence of a second type of arrhythmia when the number of measured intervals falling within a second interval range equals a second predetermined value, and delivers a second type of arrhythmia therapy in response to the detection of the second arrhythmia.

<summary>
• The invention relates to an accommodating intraocular lens device for implantation in a lens chamber of a subject's eye.
• The device comprises two lens portions, an elastically deformable lens chamber filled with a fluid or gel, and a base lens.
• The first lens provides most, if not all, of the accommodative power and the base lens provides most, if not all, of the corrective refractive power needed by a particular patient.
• The first lens must respond by changing shape or displacing along an optical axis in response to radially compressive forces exerted on the circumferential edge.
• The IOL device actuates to an accommodated state in response to radial compressive forces exerted on the outer peripheral edge, wherein the diameter of the IOL device increases.
• The opposing sides of the first lens have a thickness that is at least two times thicker than the peripheral region.
• The second lens has a thickness that is greater than either one of the opposing sides of the first lens.
• The circumferential haptic has an outer peripheral edge configured for engagement with a capsular bag of an eye when the IOL is implanted.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to esophageal electrodes and their use in medical procedures such as defibrillation and pacing the heart.
• The invention is directed to an esophageal-stomach electrode to achieve greater efficiency in the performance of such procedures.
• The electrode includes a semi-rigid plastic tube with an electrode on the distal end, which is passed through the esophagus and into the stomach.
• The distal end of the electrode can be displaced angularly within the stomach and subsequently be pulled slightly back out of the esophagus or further angularly displaced upwardly into pressurized contact with the stomach wall.
• The control mechanism for the electrode includes a slide that takes up one cord and plays out the other, enabling the distal end of the electrode to be displaced within the stomach.
• The tube is crimped to form a hinge, and a rigid pin spans the hinge, and a pair of cords connected to the pin extend within the tube and into the control mechanism.
• When the slide is moved, the pin moves within the tube, causing the distal end of the electrode to displace within the stomach.
• The invention enables the distal end of the electrode to displace angularly within the stomach and subsequently be pulled slightly back out of the esophagus or further angularly displaced upwardly into pressurized contact with the stomach wall.
• The present invention provides a more efficient and convenient way to perform medical procedures such as defibrillation and pacing the heart.
</summary>

• The invention is a board game simulating life at a lake.
• The game includes a playing board, tokens, title deed cards, game pieces, scrip, cards, and elements operable by players for randomly determining movement.
• The playing board includes a plurality of successive, contiguous spaces defining a continuous path about a periphery of the board.
• The game pieces may be purchased with scrip and placed upon acquired lake areas, dams, or boat dealerships to increase rental payments.
• The title deed cards are associated with lake areas, dams, and boat dealerships and bear indicia indicating rental payments payable to a player acquiring the property.
• The game is designed to simulate the ups and downs of life at a lake by acquiring lake properties, dams, and boat dealerships, and experiencing the penalties, awards, and directions indicated on the cards.

<summary>
* The invention relates to a device and method for treating tissues and open wounds, using a combination of fluid supply and suctioning. (0001)
* The device includes an occlusive dressing with open pores, which are applied to the wound and exposed to suctioning. (0002)
* The invention aims to improve the efficiency and safety of wound treatment by eliminating the need for hydrostatic pressure and pump head, and by providing real-time monitoring of fluid transport and suctioning. (0003)
* The invention also relates to a dressing system that allows for intermittent administration of saline or drug solution during ongoing suctioning, and a fluid administration set for treating wounded tissue. (0004)
* The invention further includes a device for preventing blocking of the dressing pores at the drainage port by biological material, and a method for detecting and warning of bleeding from a wound. (0005-0007)
* The invention provides a simple and reproducible apparatus and method for distributing treatment fluid intermittently to the wound tissue during continuous suctioning, and eliminates the need for complex electronic controls. (0008-0010)
* The invention also provides a means for reliable early detection of bleeding during ongoing suctioning, and allows for manual or automatic positioning of the fluid bag to level with the wounded tissue. (0011-0014)
* The invention further includes a supply port comprising an elastic injection membrane, which allows for intermittent administration of saline or drug solution against a resistance. (0015)
* The invention provides a dressing system that can be used for tissue regeneration, and allows for reduction of the rates of fluid transport and suctioning to leave diffusional and cellular processes undisturbed. (0016)
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to gravity-driven vehicles, such as downhill racing carts.
* The vehicle has a steerable, durable body with at least two wheels or skis.
* The vehicle is designed for riding in a prone, face-down position.
* The vehicle has at least one brake for slowing or stopping the vehicle.
* The vehicle may have a combination of wheels and skis for enhanced performance on snow-covered terrain.
* The vehicle has a suspension mechanism for precise control in turns.
* The invention provides a kit of components for retrofitting a wheeled vehicle into a gravity-driven vehicle.
* The vehicle may have an attachment for picking up the vehicle by a ski chair lift.
* The vehicle has means for harnessing the rider onto and into the vehicle.
* The invention provides a safety brake that actuates upon release of the hand grips.
* The invention also provides a means for automatically holding a constant turn upon occasion of a rider falling off the vehicle.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a wave-based imaging method that uses directing predetermined energy waves radially outward from within an interspace and receiving scattered energy waves from one or more objects.
* The received data are processed to produce images of the objects using a wave-based algorithm that can map an angular location and a plurality of frequency parameters of the received scattered energy waves to construct images of the one or more objects.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a biological oil composition derived from a marine copepod, particularly Calanus finmarchicus, and its use in preventing or treating cardiovascular disease.
• The oil composition is characterized by a high content of wax esters, low levels of triglycerides, and high levels of astaxanthin and cholesterol.
• The biological oil composition shows a significant ability to inhibit atherosclerotic plaque formation and lower total blood cholesterol levels compared to concentrated EPA/DHA.
• The oil composition is distinct from other marine oils in its chemical characteristics, particularly the high content of wax esters, and its unique effect on lipid deposition and cholesterol levels.
• The biological oil composition of the present invention is a novel anti-atherosclerotic composition that can be used as a primary prevention strategy for cardiovascular disease.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to polyelectrolyte complexes and their use in pharmaceutical compositions.
* The polyelectrolyte complexes are composed of a macromolecular, multiply charged component of one polarity and low molecular weight ions of the opposite polarity.
* The invention surprisingly found that polyelectrolyte complexes can be adapted to meet the various requirements of biocompatible (biodegradable) polymer systems and can display incorporation capacities of more than 90%.
}

* The polyelectrolyte complexes can be prepared from purely aqueous reaction solutions into which active substances, which are soluble therein, are introduced.
* The invention also relates to a process for preparing pharmaceutical compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes and active substances.
* The consistency properties of the polyelectrolyte complex/active substance formulations can be widely varied and can be specifically adjusted for diverse pharmaceutical applications.
* The invention has emerged that the cytostatic daunorubicin and the polyacid xylan polysulfate produce macroparticles which contain daunorubicin and release the latter in buffer solution or in biological systems uniformly over a lengthy period.

<summary>
* The invention relates to a golf ball teeing device that eliminates the need for an unclamping control incorporated into a long pole.
* The device can utilize a golf club as a handle and contains relatively few parts, making it lightweight and portable.
* The device can be quickly and easily used without requiring the cumbersome juggling of a large device and a golf club.
* The invention provides a golf ball teeing device that can also be used to retrieve the golf tee once the ball has been hit, for both instances of the tee laying horizontally on the ground or remaining vertically inserted into the ground.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present disclosure relates to a person support apparatus, such as a hospital or long-term care bed, with a mechanism suitable for adjusting the height and orientation of a patient support frame forming part of that bed. (0001)
* The patient support frame is supported on a deck support or intermediate frame, and the deck support frame is provided with a mechanism for adjusting the height of the deck and hence the height of the support surface above the floor on which the apparatus is located, and to control the orientation or inclination of the deck and hence the patient support surface relative to the floor. (0002-0003)
* The deck support frame is supported on leg assemblies which are pivotally connected at their upper end to the deck support frame and which have linear actuators for pivoting the leg assemblies relative to the deck support frame and hence adjusting the height of the deck support frame. (0004)
* Known arrangements for pivoting leg assemblies relative to a deck support frame to allow the raising and lowering of the deck support frame include a leg element pivotally connected at its upper end to a guide element which is coupled to and can slide along the outside of longitudinal elements arranged parallel to, or forming, the sides of the deck support frame. (0007)
* The present disclosure, in a first aspect, provides a person support apparatus comprising a person support frame for supporting a person support deck, and a support assembly for supporting the person support frame and moving it relative to a floor surface, wherein the support assembly comprises at least one leg assembly pivotally coupled at a first upper end portion to the person support frame and coupled at its second lower end portion to floor engaging means. (0010)
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a skin reflectance measuring apparatus.
* The invention finds an application in measuring the effect of products known as "anti-reflectance" products for greasy skins.
* The apparatus comprises a probe with a casing that houses an aperture, and a flexible connection in fiber optics.
* The probe is connected to a measuring device via the flexible connection, which allows for miniaturization and ease of use.
* The measuring device comprises light emitting means, light receiving means, and processing means.
* The light emitting means optically couples to a second end of the first conductor, while the light receiving means optically couples to a second end of the second conductor.
* The processing means are connected to the light emitting and receiving means and are provided with correcting means to compensate for variations in the emitted light and for the influence of ambient light.
* The resulting reflectance is a relative value worked out from measurements of the specular reflection and of the diffuse reflection.
* The invention offers several advantages, including the ability to measure the reflectance of the skin with a probe that is small enough to be easily handled and positioned on the skin.
* The use of fiber optics allows for a flexible connection that can tolerate a few degrees of deviation of relative position between the probe and the skin surface.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to dental apparatus and provides a simple and effective means for cleaning teeth and massaging the gums.
* The mouthpiece has upper and lower channel members that fit over the upper and lower teeth, respectively, and provide a sealed area between the membranes.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a needle for threading of a strap of an implant through a tissue, used for reconstructing the organs in the pelvic area. (1070)
* The needle includes a trap for trapping the strap, a tip for threading the trapped strap, and a mechanism for releasing the trap. (1010)
* The mechanism for releasing the trap is manually driven, and the needle further includes an arm for driving the mechanism. (1020)
* The invention also relates to an anterior implant including at least two straps for threading thereof into the arcus tendineous fascia pelvic ligaments, and a loop between the straps for anchoring thereof to the cervix. (1001)
* The invention also relates to a posterior implant including at least two straps for threading thereof into the sacrospinous ligaments, and a loop at the side opposing the straps for anchoring thereof to the perineal body. (1002)
* The invention provides a reliable anchoring of the mesh implant, and the trapping of the end of the strap may comprise inserting the end of the strap into a niche and grasping the end of the strap. (1003-1005)
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to methods and apparatus for the provision of ventilatory assistance matched to a subject's respiratory need.
• The ventilatory assistance can be for a subject who is either spontaneously or non-spontaneously breathing, or moves between these breathing states.
• The invention is especially suitable for, but not limited to, spontaneously breathing human subjects requiring long-term ventilatory assistance, particularly during sleep.
• The invention discloses the determination of the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle as a continuous variable.
• The invention further discloses a method for calculating the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle including at least the steps of determining...
• The invention further discloses a method for measuring the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle as a continuous variable, in which the step of calculating respiratory airflow includes a low pass filtering step to reduce non-respiratory noise.
• The invention further discloses a method for measuring the average respiratory rate, comprising the steps of measuring...
• The invention further discloses a method for providing ventilatory assistance in a spontaneously breathing subject, comprising the steps of...
• The invention further discloses a method for providing ventilatory assistance in a spontaneously breathing subject, in which the step of selecting a desired pressure modulation amplitude is a fixed amplitude.
• The invention further discloses a method for providing ventilatory assistance in a spontaneously breathing subject, in which the step of selecting a desired pressure modulation amplitude comprises the substeps of...
• The invention provides improvements over the prior art directed to any one of the stated goals.
• The invention provides a fuzzy membership function that returns a value between zero and unity.
• The invention provides a method for calculating the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle as a continuous variable from 0 to 1 revolution.
• The invention provides a method for measuring the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle as a continuous variable, in which the defuzzification step includes a correction for any phase delay introduced in the step of low pass filtering respiratory airflow.
• The invention provides a method for providing vent

<summary>
• The invention relates to surgical instruments and specifically to a novel electro-surgical dissection and cauterization instrument for use in laparoscopic/endoscopic procedures.
• The instrument includes a rigid insulating sleeve that surrounds a conducting rod extending from the proximal end to the distal end of the instrument, which includes a working tip electrode.
• The distal end of the instrument includes a rigid arm that extends from the sleeve and includes portions laterally offset from the longitudinal axis of the sleeve.
• The working tip electrode is formed at the free end of the arm and is used to make direct contact with the patient at the internal operation site.
• The instrument provides an electrical insulating layer along the entire length of the tool up to the exposed working tip electrode to eliminate inadvertent cauterization of tissue with portions of the tool other than the working tip electrode.
• The invention is designed to overcome the problem of obstruction of the surgeon's view of the operation site by the sleeve and inadvertent cauterization of healthy tissue by the instrument.

• The present invention relates to a magnetic resonance imaging apparatus that provides high-contrast exposures in a short time, even for larger body segments.
• The invention achieves this by determining the required adjustment parameters in a preceding adjustment process and storing them until the conclusion of the examination.
• The adjustment parameters are not determined immediately before each individual exposure, but rather in a separate adjustment process that precedes the exposure process.
• The inventive apparatus uses a magnet with at least one patient receptacle and at least one support plate, as well as a predetermined number of transmit and/or receive coils.
• The support plate is displaceable within the patient receptacle to obtain larger bodily segments, and the adjustment parameters are stored for each position of the support plate.
• The adjustment process includes determining the connected configuration of the transmit coils and the receive coils, as well as the corresponding control signals for the generator, transmit amplifier, matching elements, receive amplifier, and receiver.
• In the inventive apparatus, high-contrast exposures are obtained without omitting an adjustment, and reduced examination times result due to the stored adjustment parameters.
• The invention is suitable for a large number of different forms of magnetic resonance imaging apparatuses, including cylindrical and horseshoe magnets.

<summary>
* The invention relates to fasteners for albums such as photographic albums and scrapbooks. (0001)
* The fastener has a pair of strap anchors, one on the front cover and one on the back cover, and a strap that passes between them. (0002)
* The strap anchors are in the form of channels, and the strap enters and exits the channels through apertures in their bases. (0003)
* The strap is locked within the anchors by snapping engagement beneath locking lips at the open sides of the channels. (0004)
* The invention provides an album having at least two fasteners mounted along the spine part of the album. (0005)
* The fasteners can accommodate a variable thickness of the album by adjusting the effective length of the strap between the anchors. (0006)
* The strap anchors are attached to the respective covers of the album using adhesive such as double-sided tape. (0007)
* The invention improves upon conventional screw-type fasteners by providing a releasable fastener that is easier to use and more versatile. (0008)
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a sulky comprising two wheels, individually fastened but located along the same rotational axis, to a common frame provided with a driver's seat and shafts leading towards the draught animal.
• The invention aims to provide a new sulky construction that can be manufactured of light metal and other lightweight and durable materials, and can be assembled easily by a user himself using ordinary hand tools, with all connections becoming secure without any play, even if the single components are produced with ordinary manufacturing tolerances.
• The sulky according to the present invention has a total weight of approximately 18 kg in a ready-to-use state, and the end frames are casted, preferably of aluminum or a similar light metal, using a chill-casting or press-casting process or alternatively by producing the frames of reinforced plastics.
• The crossbar is adapted to the mounting bushings and may be fastened thereto, and the driver's seat is fastened to the crossbar by means of extruded brackets that may be clamped thereto by conventional clamping devices.
• The crossbar and the fastening of the same in one of the mounting bushings is shown in more detail at the cross section, and the strengthening elements may be shifted along the aluminum profile to a suitable place so that the threaded holes coincide with the assembling recesses in the profile and the mounting bushing.
• The mounting bushing has a cross section that with a certain play is adapted to the external section of the extruded aluminum profile which constitutes the crossbar, and the loads are evenly distributed due to the symmetrical design of the end frames relative to the wheel planes.
• The end frames are preferably casted in the same tool and are therefore quite identical when casted, and the tool expenses and storing charges are reduced, and the number of spare parts is also reduced.
• An important advantage of the present invention is that the complete sulky may be packed into a flat box for storing and transportation to distributors, and the user may then buy the sulky as a construction kit and mount the parts himself in a quarter of an hour and then obtain a reliable and professional sulky having a lower total

* The present invention relates to rotating water feeds and their ventilation systems.
* The invention aims to provide a solution for removing air or gas bubbles accumulating in rotating pipes, such as water feeds of water-cooled generators.
* The invention provides an arrangement that automatically removes or reduces air or gas bubbles by utilizing the pressure gradient between the inflow and outflow of the device.

* The invention relates to a steering column for a motor vehicle, which comprises a jacket unit supporting a steering shaft rotatably about its longitudinal axis and a retaining part connected with the jacket unit non-displaceably in a limit value of a force acting onto the jacket unit parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the front of the motor vehicle.

* If the limit value is exceeded, the jacket unit is displaceable parallel to the longitudinal axis in the direction toward the motor vehicle front, and the retaining part is connected with the jacket unit across an energy absorption connection, which comprises at least one bending wire or strip that is deformed upon displacement of the jacket unit with respect to the retaining part.

* The invention further relates to a method for the production of such a steering column, and an advantageous embodiment provides that the retaining part is formed by a part of the securement device, and the energy absorption device is integrated into the securement device.

• The present invention relates to a process for mounting glass panels in curved window bays of motor vehicles.
• The invention provides an improved method overcoming the disadvantages of the prior art, such as distortion of the glass during tempering and contouring, and the cost of pre-contoured glass.
• The method involves placing a flat, uncontoured glass panel within the curved window bay and securing it along the edge of the bay with resilient clips.
• The clips are cooperatively secured to a reveal molding, which provides a resilient bias pressing on the outer surface of the glass panel.
• The glass panel is flexed from its initial flat configuration into the conforming curvature of the window, and a weather sealant and adhesive compound are applied in situ along the confronting edges of the window panel.
• The adhesive cures until the panel becomes fixed permanently in the window opening in its conforming curvature.
• The fastening means comprises a plurality of resilient clips uniformly spaced about the perimeter of the window bay.
• The reveal molding cooperatively secured to the clips provides a resilient bias pressing on the outer surface of the glass panel.
• The invention is applicable to installations in other vehicle windows or the like, and the curable adhesive used is preferably polysulfide.
• The present invention is a cost-effective solution that overcomes the disadvantages of the prior art and provides a simple, efficient method for installing glass panels in curved window bays.

<summary>
* The invention relates to methods and apparatus for removing a gas from a liquid, particularly oxygen from water in an offshore hydrocarbon recovery platform.
* The apparatus includes a vessel for receiving a flow of liquid having a first gas mixed therewith, and mechanisms for ingesting and mixing a second gas into the liquid for creating a turbulent area and displacing the first gas to an upper portion or vapor space for removal.
</summary>

• The present disclosure relates to a packaging machine with a simplified, more compact design.

• The machine comprises a rotationally driven shaft arranged in the production direction of the packaging machine.

• The shaft and each of the movable tool members of various work stations are provided with a transfer mechanism for converting the rotational movement of the shaft into the movement required to operate the respective tool member.

• The transfer mechanism is rendered robust and independent of high wear components, such as a belt.

• The shaft is driven in a continuous 360° rotation, which allows a transmission between the shaft and the shaft driving unit to have a comparatively simple structural design.

• Work stations of the packaging machine whose tool members are driven by the shaft to execute a lifting movement are arranged on different vertical levels, which can render the structural design of the packaging machine more compact.

• A frame is provided for supporting the shaft, which is adequate to stabilize the shaft and prevent the generation of vibrations in the packaging machine.

• Depending on the type of work station whose tool member is to be operated, two transfer mechanisms may be provided for lifting the cutting tool of the cross separator on either side of the packaging foil web, which prevents canting of the cutting tool and guarantees a reliable, continuous cut through the web of packaging foil.

• The invention relates to a finishing article with a drive member non-removably affixed thereto for mounting on a rotatable spindle of a power tool.
• The drive member includes a backing flange with gripping means radially extending therefrom secured by a retaining nut positioned on the opposite side from the backing flange.
• The retaining nut extends through an opening in the finishing article from the face toward the back of the finishing article and has a radial flange at one end thereof seated against the finishing article face.
• The pressure cap defines a central opening and is held in place by the gripping means on the backing flange and extends longitudinally away from the backing flange to engage the power tool spindle seat.
• The gripping means on the backing flange includes a plurality of radially outwardly extending fingers formed therein.
• The fingers are preferably formed during the stamping operation when the backing flange is fabricated from stamped sheet metal.
• The purpose of the gripping means is to non-removably secure the retaining nut and the backing flange together on the finishing article without the use of adhesives.
• The disposable finishing article assembly is constructed in accordance with the principles of the present invention and mounted in operable position on the spindle of a power tool.
• The finishing article may take many forms, such as grinding wheels, flap wheels, wire wheels, abrasive disks or pads, or the like.

<summary>
* The invention relates to a hydraulic unit for a vehicle brake system, which includes a housing block, a motor, and a plurality of pistons that are embodied as a cam element.
* The cam element is disposed in an eccentric chamber, and the pistons are connected to a shaft that is rotatable within the eccentric chamber.
</summary>

<summary>* The invention relates to a power and free conveyor system where a carrier is transferred from one predetermined path to another by pushing across a transfer zone in a minimum period of time.</summary>

* The third dog is provided in longitudinally spaced relation to the first and second dogs and is normally urged to an operative carrier pushing position but is held by the track out of operative position.</summary>

* In both forms of FIGS. 7 and 8, a carrier which is not switched off is pushed all the way through the switching area by engagement of its front dog with a dog of the power chain so that the trailing dogs move through this area without being in contact with a dog.</summary>

• The invention relates to a grounding product for railroad car center plate assembly bowl liners.
• The liner material used herein has similar mechanical properties to the liner as disclosed in Chierici and Murphy U.S. Pat. No. 4,075,951, but has improved electrical properties.
• The disclosures in Wulff U.S. Pat. No. 4,241,667 and Chierici and Murphy U.S. Pat. No. 4,075,951 are incorporated by reference.
• Railroad cars are commonly in the form of a body resting on and swivelly connected to a pair of trucks adjacent each end of the car.
• The Chierici and Murphy patent establishes two slip surfaces in the center plate assembly, one on either side of the bowl liner, that insures adequate truck swiveling action even under severe operating contingencies, and further provides for a wear-resisting resurfacing of the bolster surfaces engaged by the bowl liner.
• The present invention is concerned with providing a liner with all the benefits as disclosed in the Chierici et al patent and in addition being conductive, thereby eliminating the need for any additional grounding apparatus.

<summary>
• The invention provides a valve for controlling the flow of viscous substances from a bag or pouch.
• The valve includes a tubular sleeve and a gate valve member that can be moved to open or close the flow.
• The sleeve is mounted on the spout of the bag and has a discharge outlet with a sealing edge.
• The gate valve member is reciprocated on a guide member relative to the sleeve to open or close the flow.
• The gate valve member has a curved plate that is complemental to the curvature of the guide plate.
• The gate valve member can be moved between opened and closed positions with one hand.
• The valve can function when the valve assembly is in an inclined position.
• The valve can be readily disassembled for cleaning and reassembled.
• The valve provides an effective seal and complete cut-off when the valve is closed.

• The present invention provides a vehicle rearview mirror system that is tolerant of different protocols of an output of a vehicle control. This allows the mirror system to be used with various types of vehicles without modifications to the circuit.
• The mirror system includes a variable reflective element that assumes a partial reflectance level in response to a drive signal. The mirror controller determines the protocol of the output of the vehicle control, including monitoring the output to determine when the vehicle is in reverse gear or not.

<summary>
* The present invention relates to an anti-lock braking system (ABS) for motorcycles, particularly for front wheel brakes.
* The ABS system is designed to prevent wheel lock-up during braking, which can cause the motorcycle to become unstable or lose control.
* The system uses a hydraulic pump and modulator to control the hydraulic pressure to the brake, and a pressure discharge valve to open and close the hydraulic flow to the brake when the wheel is close to locking up.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to movable partitions and bulkheads for separating cargo areas in a trailer. (0006)
* The invention includes an improved partition system with at least two panels independently attached to mounting assemblies, allowing each panel to be moved independently. (0007)
* The partition panels can be slidably attached to rails and raised into a stowed position using a lift mechanism. (0008)
* The invention can be used to create multiple cargo areas in a trailer with different temperature controls, improving efficiency and reducing strain on the temperature control system. (0009)
* The panels can be hingedly attached to a trolley assembly and moved in the fore and aft direction. (0010)
* The trolley assembly can be replaced with any mechanism that cooperates with the selected mounting means. (0011)
* The rails can be replaced with other receiving members that cooperate with the selected mounting means. (0012)
* The mounting means can include a flat slidable member that engages an interior surface of the rail member and is hingedly attached to the bulkhead. (0013)
* The rails can be mounted on a vertical surface, such as a trailer wall, and the mounting means can be selected to enable the bulkheads to swing open like a door. (0014)
* The invention can be modified to provide additional or different functionalities, such as a hinge mechanism that rotates the panel about a hinge rod. (0015)
* The strap can be attached to the base of the panel and pulled downward to lower the bulkhead into a stowed position. (0016)
</summary>

• The invention relates to a sanitizable rotary valve that may be used in conjunction with liquid chromatography and other processes.
• The valve combines elements from prior art valves but adds a unique feature of partial separation of the rotor-stator faces to allow flushing across the process fluid-contacting surfaces.
• The valve includes a rotor with a thermoplastic elastomeric diaphragm integrally molded to form multiple sealing ports, and a stator with ports fluidly connected to sanitary piping flanges.
• The valve is directed to a sliding multi-port diaphragm valve having at least two inner surfaces, and a sealing means comprising a diaphragm with rotor port sealing means and at least one dynamic wipe sealing lip.
• The invention also relates to an insert molding process for forming a rotary valve diaphragm seal, including the steps of affixing a mold base to the rotor, injecting the rotor with an elastomer, curing the diaphragm, and removing the mold and caps.

<summary>
* The present invention relates to gas-liquid contacting trays and improvements in valve-tray assemblies.
* One aspect of the invention includes an improved tray valve assembly for a process column.
* The valve cover is mounted by first and second legs, the first leg being wider than the second leg.
* The valve also includes means for selectively biasing the rear region of the valve upwardly against the flow of liquid.
* The invention also includes the above described tray valve being formed of a round disc having the first and second legs depending downwardly therefrom.

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a fluid pressure regulator assembly that generates power while regulating fluid pressure.
* The invention provides a fluid pressure regulator assembly that reduces variances in output pressure due to large differences in input pressure.
* The assembly includes a pressurized fluid source, high-pressure line, fluid regulator, output line, and burner, all well known in the art.
* The vane motor is coupled to the high-pressure line and is designed to convert pressurized fluid into mechanical motion.
* The motor is provided with a drive shaft, casing, and hollow interior that define a fluid inlet and outlet.
* The first vane assembly and second vane assembly are constructed with vanes secured to lost motion linkages, which are positioned within the hollow interior of the inner drum.
* The first lost motion linkage defines an interior space with a width approximately one-half of its length, and the guide block has a square cross-section with a width only slightly smaller than the width of the interior space.
* The drum shaft is coupled to a back plate bolted to the casing, and the drive shaft is positioned slightly higher than the drum shaft and coupled to a front plate bolted to the casing.
</summary>

* The invention relates to pallet systems that restrict both lateral and longitudinal movement of items loaded onto the pallet. * The pallet system includes a pallet with raised parallel guide rails, trays slid onto the pallet along the guide rails, and end plates secured to the stacked trays to provide stability and limit longitudinal movement.

* The pallet system provides enhanced stability when loaded and wrapped, and allows trays to be slid on and off. * The pallet can be used for automated loading and unloading of trays, and the end plates have an inside surface shaped to complement the outside surface of the stack of trays.

* The guide rails are raised above the level of a weight bearing area of the top surface of the pallet, and the end stops limit longitudinal movement of trays parallel to the guide rails. * The pallet system can be customized for its intended load, such as for supporting egg trays with slanted edges and honeycomb-shaped edges on the end plates.

* The electrical driven flying saucer based on magnetic suspension comprises a saucer shell, a saucer cabin, a rotary-wing system, and a control system. (0021)
* The rotary-wing system is a magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing system that includes magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, an electromotive ring, a magnetic suspension shaft, and a magnetic suspension guide rail. (0021)
* The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels comprise blades, a magnetic suspension inner ring, and a magnetic suspension outer ring. (0021)
* The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels are suspended on the magnetic suspension shaft in the radial direction and are embedded in the electromotive ring in the radial direction. (0022)

• The present invention relates to streptavidin muteins with improved binding affinity for peptide ligands, particularly for the peptide ligand strep-tag II. • The invention concerns polypeptides selected from muteins of streptavidin that have a higher binding affinity than wild-type streptavidin for peptide ligands comprising the amino acid sequence Trp-Xaa-His-Pro-Gln-Phe-Xaa-Xaa. • The invention also concerns nucleic acids that code for streptavidin and may be operatively linked to a signal peptide, such as the OmpA signal peptide.

<summary>
• The present invention relates to methods of forming substituted guanidines using nickel catalysts.
• The methods involve treating guanylating agents with a compound selected from the group consisting of amines in the presence of a nickel catalyst.
• The nickel catalysts used in the inventive methods preferably comprise nickel in the zero oxidation state.
• Suitable guanylating agents are thioureas and isothioureas, which have the respective general formulas.
• The invention also relates to the use of N-arylsulfonyl protected methylisothioureas to guanylate aliphatic and cyclic amines in the presence of a nickel catalyst.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a novel apparatus and method for continuously electrolytically coloring aluminum strips or wires.
2. The invention involves an anodic oxidation bath for anodizing the aluminum strip or wire and an electrolytic coloring bath for electrolytically coloring the anodized aluminum strip or wire.
3. The anodic oxidation bath composition contains an aqueous solution of 10 to 55% sulfuric acid, and optionally, a salt such as magnesium chloride, sodium sulfate, magnesium sulfate, sodium chloride, etc.
4. The electrolytic coloring bath contains at least one of a nickel salt, a cobalt salt, a copper salt, a tin salt, and selenious acid.
5. The electric current used in the anodic oxidation can be a direct current or direct and alternating superposed currents.
6. The aluminum strip or wire having the oxide film or layer formed in the anodization is continuously immersed in the electrolytic bath.
7. The color of the oxide film formed can be controlled by the composition of the electrolytic bath and the electrolytic conditions.
8. The current density and the electrolytic period of time in the bath are controlled by the area of the aluminum strip or wire immersed, the amount of electric current applied, and the period of immersion of the aluminum strip or wire.
9. The apparatus of this invention will be explained practically by the embodiment illustrated in the accompanying drawing.
10. The invention provides an apparatus and method for continuously conducting an anodic oxidation and electrolytic coloring of an aluminum strip or wire without need for a large amount of electrical energy.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a process of producing transgenic plants or plant cells transformed on a chromosome with a DNA sequence of interest.
* The process involves providing plant cells or plants with at least two different vectors that can recombine with each other to produce a non-replicating recombination product containing the DNA sequence of interest.
* The DNA sequence of interest contains sequence portions from at least two of the at least two different vectors, which are necessary for expressing a function of interest from the DNA sequence of interest.
* The process has many important applications, including DNA library screening, gene function analysis, and directed evolution, and can be used to introduce a gene to be expressed in a chromosome of a plant cell or plant.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a swash plate type compressor with a cylinder block and rotary shaft carrying an aluminum swash plate.
* The swash plate has two facial surfaces and an end surface, and the facial surfaces are coated with a polyfluoro elastomer-based coating.
* The coating includes lubricious and load bearing additives to provide durability and low coefficient of friction.
* The coating is applied by spraying the polyfluoro elastomer with a liquid carrier, and the ratio of liquid to solid portions is between 40% to 90%.
* The swash plate is usually manufactured by a forging process and requires machining to achieve final production tolerance.
* The coating process does not require a high surface finish on the swash plate, and the surface roughening can be formed by abrasive grit blasting or electro-discharge machining.
* The coated swash plate has a low friction coefficient and is made from non-hypereutectic aluminum or aluminum alloys containing less than 10% silicon.
* The coating is cured in an oven at an elevated temperature, and the swash plate facial surfaces and end surface may be simultaneously coated.
* The piston shoe may also be coated with the fluorocarbon coating to further increase the low friction properties of the compressor.
* The invention provides a swash plate with a durable coating that reduces friction and wear, and the coating can be applied to non-hypereutectic aluminum or aluminum alloys.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to organic polymers suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings on semiconductor devices, particularly for photolithography processes using KrF and ArF light sources.
* The polymers of the present invention are designed to absorb light strongly at wavelengths of 193 nm and 248 nm, and are suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings to prevent standing wave effects and light reflection in lithography processes.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a white, flame-retardant, UV-resistant, thermoformable, oriented film made from a crystallizable thermoplastic, with a thickness of from 10 to 350 μm. The film comprises at least one white pigment and one flame retardant and has good orientability and thermoformability, and very good optical and mechanical properties, and can be produced cost-effectively.
• The film is intended to pass the UL 94 test “Vertical Burning Test for Flammability of Plastic Material” and is classified in class 94 VTM-0, meaning that it ceases to burn after 30 seconds in the Bunsen burner test and does not embrittle or crack after exposure to heat.

<summary>
• The present invention relates to an improved method for producing 143a by continuous gas phase hydrofluorination of 1,1-dichloroethane using heterogeneous catalysis.
• The invention provides a new practical process for the production of 143a with very high conversion and selectivity (both over 99%) for 143a.
• The catalyst claimed in the invention is a combination of iron oxide, rare earth oxide, and zirconium oxide.
• The lifetime of the catalyst was not reported.
• U.S. Pat. No. 3,287,424 discloses the hydrofluorination of 1,1,1-trichloroethane to 1,1,1-trifluoroethane in a batch process using arsenic trifluoride as a fluorinating agent and antimony pentafluoride as a catalyst.
• U.S. Pat. No. 3,803,241 uses a catalyst composed of chromium (III) chloride supported on alumina, which was dried at 200° C. using nitrogen or air, followed by HF activation at 250° C. for 2 hours.
• U.S. Pat. No. 3,833,676 discloses a catalyst composed of boric acid mixed with pseudoboehmite alumina, which was activated using hydrogen fluoride at 350° C. using 2 mole/hr HF and 1 mole/hr nitrogen.
• U.S. Pat. No. 3,904,701 discloses a bismuth containing catalyst supported on alumina, which was prepared by soaking alpha-alumina in a mannitol solution of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 .5H 2  O.
• The invention provides an improved method for producing 143a by continuous gas phase hydrofluorination of 1,1-dichloroethane using heterogeneous catalysis.
• The invention provides a new practical process for the production of 143a with very high conversion and

<summary>
• The invention relates to an improved process for the deacylation and desulfurization of compounds having the formula: • The process involves the use of hypophosphorous acid, which reduces the amount of elemental sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities formed during the reaction.
• The process improves the yield of the desired product and reduces the amount of by-products, making it a significant advance in the art.
• The invention provides a process for the preparation of a 3,6-di-substituted-1H-pyrazolo[5,1-c]-1,2,4-triazole from a 3,6-disubstituted-7H-1,2,4-triazolo[3,4-b]-[1,3,4]thiadiazine.
• The process involves reacting the thiadiazine with an acylating agent to form an acylated intermediate, and then reacting the acylated intermediate with an aqueous mixture of hypophosphorous acid and hydrochloric acid or hydrobromic acid.
• The use of hypophosphorous acid in the process has several advantages, including the generation of H2S rather than sulfur, ease of separation of the product from the reaction mixture, and the ability to use a catalytic amount of a Bronsted or Lewis acid.
• The process can be conducted at a temperature within the range of from about 20° C. to about 200° C., and the reaction time is usually complete in from about 0.5 to about 24 hours.

* The invention relates to a method and apparatus for forming fiber mixtures by sequentially taking small quantities of fiber from different fiber lots.
* The method involves measuring the entire momentary quantity of each fiber lot prior to the first pass, calculating a partial quantity that corresponds to a predetermined proportion of the momentary entire quantity, and removing the calculated partial quantity from the fiber bale in sequence.
* The partial quantities are removed from each fiber bale in a predetermined number of passes, and the last partial quantity remaining in each fiber bale is processed during the last pass.
* The method ensures that all fiber bales are opened without fiber residuals and that an optimally homogeneous mixture is obtained.
* The apparatus includes a bale opener for removing fibers from the various stored fiber lots, a quantity measuring device associated with the opener, and a control device that controls the mode of operation of the opener.

• The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for forming bias laid, non-woven fabrics.
• The invention involves using a rake mechanism synchronized with, but driven separately from, the conveyors, yarn carrying means, and bonding mechanism to achieve parallelism of successive courses.
• The rake mechanism accepts and retains the yarns being carried by the yarn carrying means at either end of the extremities of travel, and places the yarns onto or between the needles of the conveyors.
• The rake mechanism moves a slight distance in the same direction as the conveyors to trap the yarns, and then moves backward against the direction of travel of the conveyor to release the yarns to the conveyor needles.
• The amount of movement of the rake in this additional direction varies with the thickness of the yarn being employed.
• The invention allows for complete parallelism within each layer, with or without overlap, and the overlapped portions are parallel with the yarns of the first course.

• The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for inserting different weft threads in and through warp sheds in a multiple-color air jet loom.
• The invention aims to provide a method and apparatus for inserting different weft threads in and through warp sheds in a multiple-color air jet loom, in which air under pressure is ejected from a main nozzle unit or a main nozzle unit and subnozzles to produce different weft carrying forces suited respectively for the different weft threads for thereby carrying the weft threads, one at a time, through the warp shed at the same speed under stable conditions and preventing undue consumption of pressurized air.
• The invention provides a method and apparatus for inserting different weft threads in and through warp sheds in a multiple-color air jet loom, in which air under pressure is ejected from a main nozzle unit or a main nozzle unit and subnozzles to produce different weft carrying forces suited respectively for the different weft threads for thereby carrying the weft threads, one at a time, through the warp shed at the same speed under stable conditions and preventing undue consumption of pressurized air.
• The invention provides a method and apparatus for inserting different weft threads in and through warp sheds in a multiple-color air jet loom, in which air under pressure is ejected from a main nozzle unit or a main nozzle unit and subnozzles to produce different weft carrying forces suited respectively for the different weft threads for thereby carrying the weft threads, one at a time, through the warp shed at the same speed under stable conditions and preventing undue consumption of pressurized air.

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a technical field of bast fibre yarn and its production process, which has the advantages of improving work efficiency and quality of products.
* The invention provides a process for spinning bast fibres, including health preserving, opening, cleaning, carding, drawing, and spinning, and the temperature and humidity conditions for each step are optimized.
* The invention also provides a multi-fibre yarn produced by blending bast fibres with other fibres, and the weight percentage of bast fibres in the blended fibres can be adjusted according to the desired quality and performance.
</summary>

• The present invention relates to methods and apparatus for measuring and removing rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of nip presses, particularly those using imbedded sensors in covered rolls.
• The invention provides a more accurate measurement of the true nip pressure profile and compensates for rotational variability to produce a more accurate display of the pressure distribution across the nip region of the press. The present invention can also provide information on the wear of the cover and allow for the calculation and display of a rotational variability profile, providing the operator with additional real-time information concerning the dynamics of the pressure readings to obtain a more accurate nip pressure profile.

<summary>
* The invention relates to an apparatus mounted on an ironing board for guiding a cord of an iron and providing a holder for an article.
* The article has a clamp section for releasably securing the apparatus to the ironing board, and a flexible cord support is pivotably attached to the clamp for supporting the electrical cord of the electrical appliance above the ironing board.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to buttonhole controlling devices for sewing machines.
* The device includes a foot pad that attaches to a presser bar, and a travelling assembly with an initial position relative to the foot pad.
* The travelling assembly moves with work fed during sewing of a buttonhole and includes a slidable member that can be positioned by a button for which a buttonhole is to be sewn.
* The device can be rendered effective regardless of the type of material being sewn to cause buttonhole stitching to close without overlap.
* The adjustable stop mounted on the travelling assembly engages the tripping lever to terminate the formation of a buttonhole.
* By properly positioning the stop, an operator can precisely define the closure point and prevent the formation of an open buttonhole or one in which stitches overlap.
* The device includes a gaging element with an upstanding abutment and a set of rails shaped to overlie and slide on the rails of the shoe.
* The adjustable stop includes a screw with a threaded connection and a knob to facilitate turning by an operator.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to an apparatus for treating a dyed or printed textile web with a liquid.
* The apparatus includes a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch.
* The dwell stretch is designed to conduct the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop.
</summary>

1. The apparatus comprises an endless sieve belt for transporting the textile web along a predetermined path.
2. The liquid applicator is disposed at a first station along the path for applying the liquid to the web during motion thereof along the path.
3. The suction device is disposed at a second station along the path for removing the liquid from the web by suction during motion of the web along the path.
4. The dwell stretch is disposed between the applicator and the suction device for conducting the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop.
5. The dwell stretch device is formed by an air pass, wherein the textile web is completely free of support or guiding elements at least along major portions of the dwell stretch or loop and is accordingly accessible to the atmosphere at all sides.
6. The dwell stretch device includes at least one freely rotatable drum disposed above the upper section of the sieve belt.
